title: Nonsuch 324
text:
The Nonsuch 324 is a Canadian <a href="sailboat">sailboat</a>, that was designed by <a href="Mark%20Ellis%20Design">Mark Ellis Design</a> and first built in 1994. It was the last of the <a href="Nonsuch%20%28sailboat%29">series of Nonsuch sailboats</a> built.
The Nonsuch 324 is a development of the <a href="Nonsuch%2030">Nonsuch 30</a>, with the same hull design, but a taller rig, more sail area, a <a href="carbon%20fibre">carbon fibre</a> <a href="wishbone%20boom">wishbone boom</a> and a shallow-draft <a href="wing%20keel">wing keel</a>.
Production.
The design was built by <a href="Hinterhoeller%20Yachts">Hinterhoeller Yachts</a> in <a href="St.%20Catharines%2C%20Ontario">St. Catharines, Ontario</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, but only a small number were completed before production ended.
Design.
The Nonsuch 324 is a small recreational <a href="keelboat">keelboat</a>, built predominantly of <a href="fiberglass">fiberglass</a>. It has a <a href="Catboat">cat rig</a>, an unstayed mast with a carbon fibre wishbone boom, a <a href="plumb%20stem">plumb stem</a>, a vertical <a href="Transom%20%28nautical%29">transom</a>, an internally-mounted spade-type <a href="rudder">rudder</a> controlled by a <a href="Ship%27s%20wheel">wheel</a> and a fixed wing keel. It displaces and carries of ballast.
The boat has a draft of with the standard wing keel.
The boat is fitted with a Japanese <a href="Yanmar">Yanmar</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a> of . The fuel tank holds and the fresh water tank has a capacity of .
The design has a <a href="Performance%20Handicap%20Racing%20Fleet">PHRF</a> racing average handicap of 175 and a <a href="hull%20speed">hull speed</a> of .
